LanguageData.VAECaves_GiantSpider.label: giant spider
LanguageData.VAECaves_GiantSpider.description:
A type of arthropod, Giant Spiders are in fact nowhere near the size of the common house spiders humans are used to. However, similar rules apply - they lay eggs in spider lairs, sting their prey with venomous stinger and wrap it in cocoons for when the time is right to feast. They regenerate their wounds fast and are very susceptible to fire.

The mature giant spider is the most commonly met life stage of a giant spider. Their powerful fang bite will stun their prey for a very long period of time, giving the giant spider enough time to wrap it in the spidersilk cocoon.

Special mechanics: If attacked, all other giant spiders nearby, in any life stage, will enrage and assault the colony. Note that spider cocoons will suffocate any person, even sanguophages.
